lines.text: Enter PHILARIO, IACHIMO, a Frenchman, a Dutchman, and a Spaniard

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Believe it, sir, I have seen him in Britain: he was then of a crescent note, expected to prove so worthy as since he hath been allowed the name of; but I could then have looked on him without the help of admiration, though the catalogue of his endowments had been tabled by his side and I to peruse him by items.

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: You speak of him when he was less furnished than now he is with that which makes him both without and within.

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: I have seen him in France: we had very many there could behold the sun with as firm eyes as he.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: This matter of marrying his king's daughter, wherein he must be weighed rather by her value than his own, words him, I doubt not, a great deal from the matter.

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: And then his banishment.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Ay, and the approbation of those that weep this lamentable divorce under her colours are wonderfully to extend him; be it but to fortify her judgment, which else an easy battery might lay flat, for taking a beggar without less quality. But how comes it he is to sojourn with you? How creeps acquaintance?

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: His father and I were soldiers together; to whom I have been often bound for no less than my life. Here comes the Briton: let him be so entertained amongst you as suits, with gentlemen of your knowing, to a stranger of his quality. I beseech you all, be better known to this gentleman; whom I commend to you as a noble friend of mine: how worthy he is I will leave to appear hereafter, rather than story him in his own hearing.
Enter POSTHUMUS LEONATUS

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: Sir, we have known together in Orleans.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Since when I have been debtor to you for courtesies, which I will be ever to pay and yet pay still.

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: Sir, you o'er-rate my poor kindness: I was glad I did atone my countryman and you; it had been pity you should have been put together with so mortal a purpose as then each bore, upon importance of so slight and trivial a nature.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: By your pardon, sir, I was then a young traveller; rather shunned to go even with what I heard than in my every action to be guided by others' experiences: but upon my mended judgment--if I offend not to say it is mended--my quarrel was not altogether slight.

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: 'Faith, yes, to be put to the arbitrement of swords, and by such two that would by all likelihood have confounded one the other, or have fallen both.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Can we, with manners, ask what was the difference?

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: Safely, I think: 'twas a contention in public, which may, without contradiction, suffer the report. It was much like an argument that fell out last night, where each of us fell in praise of our country mistresses; this gentleman at that time vouching--and upon warrant of bloody affirmation--his to be more fair, virtuous, wise, chaste, constant-qualified and less attemptable than any the rarest of our ladies in France.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: That lady is not now living, or this gentleman's opinion by this worn out.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: She holds her virtue still and I my mind.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: You must not so far prefer her 'fore ours of Italy.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Being so far provoked as I was in France, I would abate her nothing, though I profess myself her adorer, not her friend.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: As fair and as good--a kind of hand-in-hand comparison--had been something too fair and too good for any lady in Britain. If she went before others I have seen, as that diamond of yours outlustres many I have beheld. I could not but believe she excelled many: but I have not seen the most precious diamond that is, nor you the lady.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: I praised her as I rated her: so do I my stone.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: What do you esteem it at?

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: More than the world enjoys.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Either your unparagoned mistress is dead, or she's outprized by a trifle.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: You are mistaken: the one may be sold, or given, if there were wealth enough for the purchase, or merit for the gift: the other is not a thing for sale, and only the gift of the gods.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Which the gods have given you?

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Which, by their graces, I will keep.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: You may wear her in title yours: but, you know, strange fowl light upon neighbouring ponds. Your ring may be stolen too: so your brace of unprizable estimations; the one is but frail and the other casual; a cunning thief, or a that way accomplished courtier, would hazard the winning both of first and last.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Your Italy contains none so accomplished a courtier to convince the honour of my mistress, if, in the holding or loss of that, you term her frail. I do nothing doubt you have store of thieves; notwithstanding, I fear not my ring.

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: Let us leave here, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Sir, with all my heart. This worthy signior, I thank him, makes no stranger of me; we are familiar at first.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: With five times so much conversation, I should get ground of your fair mistress, make her go back, even to the yielding, had I admittance and opportunity to friend.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: No, no.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: I dare thereupon pawn the moiety of my estate to your ring; which, in my opinion, o'ervalues it something: but I make my wager rather against your confidence than her reputation: and, to bar your offence herein too, I durst attempt it against any lady in the world.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: You are a great deal abused in too bold a persuasion; and I doubt not you sustain what you're worthy of by your attempt.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: A repulse: though your attempt, as you call it, deserve more; a punishment too.

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: Gentlemen, enough of this: it came in too suddenly; let it die as it was born, and, I pray you, be better acquainted.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Would I had put my estate and my neighbour's on the approbation of what I have spoke!

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: What lady would you choose to assail?

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Yours; whom in constancy you think stands so safe. I will lay you ten thousand ducats to your ring, that, commend me to the court where your lady is, with no more advantage than the opportunity of a second conference, and I will bring from thence that honour of hers which you imagine so reserved.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: I will wage against your gold, gold to it: my ring I hold dear as my finger; 'tis part of it.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: You are afraid, and therein the wiser. If you buy ladies' flesh at a million a dram, you cannot preserve it from tainting: but I see you have some religion in you, that you fear.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: This is but a custom in your tongue; you bear a graver purpose, I hope.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: I am the master of my speeches, and would undergo what's spoken, I swear.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Will you? I shall but lend my diamond till your return: let there be covenants drawn between's: my mistress exceeds in goodness the hugeness of your unworthy thinking: I dare you to this match: here's my ring.

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: I will have it no lay.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: By the gods, it is one. If I bring you no sufficient testimony that I have enjoyed the dearest bodily part of your mistress, my ten thousand ducats are yours; so is your diamond too: if I come off, and leave her in such honour as you have trust in, she your jewel, this your jewel, and my gold are yours: provided I have your commendation for my more free entertainment.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: I embrace these conditions; let us have articles betwixt us. Only, thus far you shall answer: if you make your voyage upon her and give me directly to understand you have prevailed, I am no further your enemy; she is not worth our debate: if she remain unseduced, you not making it appear otherwise, for your ill opinion and the assault you have made to her chastity you shall answer me with your sword.

lines.speaker: iachimo
lines.text: Your hand; a covenant: we will have these things set down by lawful counsel, and straight away for Britain, lest the bargain should catch cold and starve: I will fetch my gold and have our two wagers recorded.

lines.speaker: posthumus leonatus
lines.text: Agreed.
Exeunt POSTHUMUS LEONATUS and IACHIMO

lines.speaker: frenchman
lines.text: Will this hold, think you?

lines.speaker: philario
lines.text: Signior Iachimo will not from it. Pray, let us follow 'em.
Exeunt
